repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
731e616a79 made it so passing `{env = nil, clear_env = true }` would
pass `{env = {}}` to `vim.uv.spawn`.

However this is not what `clear_env` is (arguably) supposed to do.
If `env=nil` then that implies the uses wants `vim.uv.spawn()` to use
the default environment. Adding `clear_env = true` simply prevents
`NVIM` (the base environment) from being added.

Fixes #34730

<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

comment_data.body: seems unintuitive that `clear_env=true` does not clear the env.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -93,6 +93,27 @@ describe('vim.system', function()
         )
       end)
 
+      it('can set environment with clear_env = true and env = nil', function()
+        exec_lua(function()
+          vim.env.TEST = 'TESTVAL'
+        end)
+
+        -- Not passing env with clear_env should not clear the environment

comment_data.body: I agree, but there is a real regression that is being fixed here. `clear_env` isn't a good name, but it is documented properly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -93,6 +93,27 @@ describe('vim.system', function()
         )
       end)
 
+      it('can set environment with clear_env = true and env = nil', function()
+        exec_lua(function()
+          vim.env.TEST = 'TESTVAL'
+        end)
+
+        -- Not passing env with clear_env should not clear the environment

comment_data.body:
is this for performance? would it resolve your use-case if we stored a module-level env table and returned it here ?
```suggestion
    return _base_env
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -208,13 +208,18 @@ end
 --- @param clear_env? boolean
 --- @return string[]?
 local function setup_env(env, clear_env)
+  if not env and clear_env then
+    return

comment_data.body: The env could change, and we even have a test for this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -208,13 +208,18 @@ end
 --- @param clear_env? boolean
 --- @return string[]?
 local function setup_env(env, clear_env)
+  if not env and clear_env then
+    return

comment_data.body:
> is this for performance? 

It's partly for:
- performance (though arguably might be a uop)
- fixing a regression
- working towards the original intent of `vim.system` which was to replace uses of `vim.uv.spawn`, and thus all the extra functionality it provides has an opt-out, e.g. setting `stdout/stderr=false`.

I might be overthinking it, but for now this is low risk and fixes downstream issues.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -208,13 +208,18 @@ end
 --- @param clear_env? boolean
 --- @return string[]?
 local function setup_env(env, clear_env)
+  if not env and clear_env then
+    return

comment_regular_data.body:
> Adding `clear_env = true` simply prevents `NVIM` (the base environment) from being added.

The current behavior on master is how `jobstart` works, and seems more intuitive. 

But I can understand the rationale, so my comments aren't blockers. Will try to improve the docs.

One of the motiviations for `{env = nil, clear_env=true}` behaviour, is to avoid building the env table every time we invoke `vim.system()`.

If we can set `NVIM` into the server environment, that would simplify and optimize things here, and also give more motivation to change the meaning of `clear_env`. Do you think that is possible?

> If we can set `NVIM` into the server environment, that would simplify and optimize things here,

Don't see a way to do that without introducing different problems. Currently if `$NVIM` is defined, it unambiguously means "this process (which may be an Nvim process) is a child of Nvim".

Hmm ok. For 99% of use cases, I don't think `$NVIM` is useful to have, e.g.: git, shell commands, so being able to avoid building the env table is desirable. Right now the only way to do that is to pass `{env = nil, clear_env = true}`.

> For 99% of use cases, I don't think `$NVIM` is useful to have

Sure, but same for `$TMUX`, `$VIMRUNTIME`, etc. They are there for the 1% where they are really needed.

~~Maybe [`base_env`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/e91224bfaa043bb85cdfa6394f417e400522ff53/runtime/lua/vim/_system.lua#L197) should never set `$NVIM` when `clear_env=true` ? But *that* would also differ vs `jobstart()`, and I haven't thought through the tradeoff matrix...~~

Let's try this PR as is for now

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(vim.system): env=nil passes env=nil to uv.spawn
